Article: SAN FRANCISCO â Hardware startup accelerators continue to speed up, expanding their markets and funding sources, according to one pioneer. China is increasingly driving the action, said executives from Hax, who gave their annual report card on the segment here. Hax was among the first of dozens of companies around the world now teaching entrepreneurs rapid prototyping, crowdfunding, supply-chain logistics and marketing. They graduate classes multiple times a year in a business thatâs all about volume and speed. âOur goals are time to market and time to scale. We want to get 90 percent of our companies to ship a product, 90 percent of them to get to $1 million in revenue and 90 percent of them to get to $3 million,â said Cyril Ebersweiler, who claims the more than 200 startups in his portfolio netted nearly $500 million in revenue last year. One of the acceleratorâs current stars is Joy, which raised nearly $1.5 million on Indiegogo for its $69 Octopus smartwatch for kids expected to ship in July, 18 months after it was formed. Another is Makeblock, a China-based designer of educational robotic toys that has raised more than $30 million and already has 400 employees and its own retail outlets. Launched in Shenzhen in 2011 as Haxlr8r, Hax initially focused on consumer markets and the emerging Internet of Things. In the past two years it has expanded significantly into health, business and industrial markets. Startupsâ products range from devices to support better sleep to hyperspectral cameras for precision agriculture. While crowdfunding remains central, Hax is also exploring new funding sources. It expects to try with a fertility startup its first so-called mini-IPO under Regulation A+ rules in the U.S. The bitcoin community is promoting sales of securities based on crypto-currency that Ebersweiler said he expects hardware startups to try soon.  Separately, at least four insurance companies are now partnering with makers of various smart home devices, said Benjamin Joffe, based in Haxâs Shenzhen office. Accelerators are getting more savvy, said Joffe. Five years ago, half of Haxâs first classes failed to get to market. Today more than 70 percent of them ship a product, he said. Hax brought 80 of its companies to the Eureka Park startup exhibit at CES in January, more than came from Canada and Japan combined, he said. âThe gap between hardware startups and makers is widening,â he added, noting Hax shifted last year from attending Maker Faire to CES. China is one of the biggest engines for growth in hardware startups, he said, noting Xiaomi alone has incubated several including Ninebot, a designer of electric scooters. It has outpaced the U.S. in the size of early venture rounds for hardware startups, and it is set to surpass Japan this year as the second largest generator of patents worldwide, he said. The Hax event attracted about 200 people, including representatives of established companies such as Google, Hewlett Packard and Sony.
